name: Vienna
fun_fact: Fun fact: Vienna's coffee house culture is so distinctive that UNESCO declared it intangible cultural heritage in 2011. The official report notes that 'the coffeehouses are a place where patrons consume time and space, but only the coffee appears on the bill.' Leon Trotsky and Sigmund Freud were regulars.

hero_dishes.name: Wiener Schnitzel
hero_dishes.description: Wafer-thin veal cutlet pounded flat, coated in breadcrumbs, and fried to crisp golden perfection - served with potato salad and lemon wedge
hero_dishes.origin_story: Austrian law decrees that genuine Wiener Schnitzel must be veal (pork or chicken versions must be labeled differently). The dish possibly came from Milan's cotoletta, brought to Vienna during Habsburg rule. The key is pounding the veal paper-thin and frying it quickly so the breading puffs away from the meat, creating crispy waves.

hero_dishes.name: Sachertorte
hero_dishes.description: Dense chocolate cake with apricot jam filling, covered in dark chocolate ganache - served with unsweetened whipped cream
hero_dishes.origin_story: Invented in 1832 by 16-year-old apprentice Franz Sacher for Prince Metternich. His son Eduard opened Hotel Sacher in 1876, where the cake became legendary. The recipe is a closely guarded secret. Hotel Sacher and Caf√© Demel fought a nine-year legal battle over who makes the 'original' - both won rights to claim authenticity.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Caf√© Sacher Wien at Albertinaplatz behind Opera House (original recipe, expect lines), Caf√© Demel (rival claimant to 'original' status), or Caf√© Sperl near Museumsquartier

hero_dishes.name: Tafelspitz
hero_dishes.description: Boiled prime beef in vegetable broth, traditionally served with apple-horseradish sauce, chive sauce, and roasted potatoes
hero_dishes.origin_story: Emperor Franz Joseph I's favorite dish - he reportedly ate it daily. The name means 'table tip' referring to the cut from the tip of the beef. It's Austrian comfort food at its finest, though it sounds humble. The beef is simmered for hours until melt-in-your-mouth tender, and the resulting broth is often served as soup first.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Plachutta (specializes in beef preparations, multiple locations), or traditional Viennese beisls (taverns)

hero_dishes.name: Kaiserschmarren
hero_dishes.description: Fluffy shredded pancake dusted with powdered sugar, served with plum compote or apple sauce
hero_dishes.origin_story: Legend says Emperor Franz Joseph I's cook created this when a souffl√© fell apart. The emperor loved it anyway, declaring it 'schmarrn' (nonsense). Another tale claims the emperor's wife, Sisi, refused to eat it because of her strict diet, so Franz Joseph said 'Give me that schmarrn our Emperor likes' - hence Kaiserschmarrn (Emperor's nonsense).
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Traditional coffee houses and beisls throughout Vienna, Caf√© Central, or Caf√© Hawelka

signature_drinks.name: Wiener Melange
signature_drinks.description: Viennese coffee made with espresso and steamed milk, topped with milk foam - similar to cappuccino but uniquely Viennese
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Served on a silver tray with a glass of water and the spoon resting on the rim. Viennese spend hours in coffee houses reading newspapers (provided free), writing, or discussing philosophy. The melange is sipped slowly - you're paying for the time and space, not just coffee. Waiters in black vests won't rush you even if you order just one cup over three hours.

signature_drinks.name: Heuriger Wine
signature_drinks.description: Young wine from Vienna's own vineyards, served at family-run wine taverns called Heurigen
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Vienna is the only major world capital with significant wine production within city limits. Heurigen (wine taverns) serve wine from their own grapes, often with cold buffets of traditional foods. A green branch hung above the door signals the tavern is open. Locals gather in gardens under chestnut trees, drinking Gr√ºner Veltliner or Gemischter Satz (mixed grape variety unique to Vienna).

food_culture_notes: Coffee house culture dates to 1683 when Turkish siege left behind coffee beans - first coffee house opened 1685
At coffee houses' peak in 1910s, Vienna had 600 coffeehouses - Freud, Mozart, Beethoven, Klimt all were regulars
Women weren't allowed in coffee houses until 1856
Vienna ranked world's most liveable city in 2024 by Economist Intelligence Unit (third consecutive year)
